title: The Human Heart: An Introduction
narration: Welcome to this educational video on the human heart. In this video we will explore the structure and function of this vital organ understanding how it keeps us alive and healthy.

title: Location and Size
content:
Located in the thoracic cavity.
Situated between the two lungs.
Slightly tilted to the left.
Approximately the size of a clenched fist.
image_desc: Human heart location in chest. Type: diagram
narration: The heart a mesodermally derived organ resides in the chest cavity nestled between the lungs. It's positioned slightly towards the left side of your body. Interestingly the heart is about the same size as your clenched fist making it a compact yet powerful organ.

title: Pericardium: The Heart's Protective Layer
content:
Protected by a double-walled membranous bag.
This bag is called the pericardium.
Pericardium encloses the pericardial fluid.
narration: The heart is safeguarded by a doublelayered sac known as the pericardium. This protective bag contains pericardial fluid which acts as a lubricant reducing friction as the heart beats. The pericardium ensures the heart functions smoothly within the chest cavity.

title: Chambers of the Heart
content:
The heart has four chambers.
Two upper chambers: Atria (relatively small).
Two lower chambers: Ventricles (larger).
image_desc: Four chambers of the heart. Type: diagram
narration: The human heart is divided into four distinct chambers. The two smaller upper chambers are called the atria which receive blood. The two larger lower chambers are the ventricles which pump blood out to the rest of the body.

title: Septa: Dividing the Heart
content:
Inter-atrial septum: Separates the right and left atria.
Inter-ventricular septum: Separates the left and right ventricles.
Atrio-ventricular septum: Separates the atria and ventricles on each side.
narration: The heart's chambers are separated by walls called septa. The interatrial septum divides the right and left atria while the interventricular septum separates the ventricles. Additionally the atrioventricular septum separates the atria and ventricles on each side ensuring proper blood flow.

title: Valves: Regulating Blood Flow
content:
Tricuspid valve: Guards the opening between the right atrium and right ventricle.
Bicuspid (Mitral) valve: Guards the opening between the left atrium and left ventricle.
narration: Valves play a crucial role in regulating blood flow within the heart. The tricuspid valve controls the passage of blood between the right atrium and right ventricle. Similarly the bicuspid or mitral valve regulates blood flow between the left atrium and left ventricle.

title: Semilunar Valves
content:
Semilunar valves are present in the pulmonary artery and aorta.
These valves regulate flow from the ventricles into these vessels.
image_desc: Semilunar valves in heart. Type: illustration
narration: Semilunar valves are strategically positioned at the exits of the ventricles. They are found at the opening of the right ventricle into the pulmonary artery and at the opening of the left ventricle into the aorta. These valves ensure that blood flows in the correct direction.

title: One-Way Blood Flow
content:
Valves ensure unidirectional blood flow.
From atria to ventricles.
From ventricles to pulmonary artery or aorta.
Valves prevent backward flow of blood.
image_desc: Blood flow direction in heart. Type: diagram
narration: The valves within the heart are designed to ensure blood flows in only one direction. Blood moves from the atria to the ventricles and then from the ventricles to either the pulmonary artery or the aorta. These valves prevent any backflow ensuring efficient circulation throughout the body.
